Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Do lianas alter community and ecosystem dynamics in tropical forests? A large-scale experimental test
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most notable recent changes in tropical forests is the increase in woody vine (liana) abundance and biomass. This change is important because recent evidence suggests that lianas are major contributors to ecosystem processes and tree community coexistence. Increasing lianas will likely reduce tree growth, increase tree mortality, and change soil nutrient dynamics - thus changing tropical forest carbon, water, and nutrient fluxes. Lianas also may impede growth and regeneration of tree species with high wood density more than species with lower wood density, which would further reduce forest carbon stocks and fluxes. In the Republic of Panama, PIs will establish long-term experimental forest plots in which they remove lianas from half of the plots. The PIs will measure long-term changes in carbon dynamics, soil nutrient and water availability, and tree responses to lianas.

The proposed project will be the first large-scale, long-term experimental study to quantify the role of lianas in both community- and ecosystem-level processes, and it will provide a benchmark for predicting future tropical forest changes with changing liana abundance. The project will facilitate a variety of broader impacts, including international capacity building, student mentoring, and field-based education. The PIs will actively mentor post-docs and graduate and undergraduate students from the US and Latin America, as well as use the established experimental infrastructure for US-based study-abroad programs. The project also provides experimental infrastructure for additional collaborative research on tropical forest ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lianas are woody vines and they are conspicuously abundant in tropical forests (think of what Tarzan swung on as he made his way through the “jungle”).  Lianas rely on trees for structural support to make their way to the top of the forest canopy and gain access to sunlight.  The liana growth form has evolved multiple, independent times, and lianas are a native component of tropical biodiversity worldwide.  However, for reasons that are not entirely understood, lianas appear to be increasing in abundance in tropical forests.  Tropical forests store vast amounts of carbon in biomass and soils, and thus have large feedbacks on the global carbon cycle.  The goal of our project was to investigate how lianas affect tropical forest carbon cycling, and whether the tropical forest carbon sink and storage functions may be compromised by increasing liana abundance.  We hypothesized that heavy liana abundance reduces tropical forest productivity and carbon storage, because lianas can reduce tree growth through competition for resources such as water and light, and may also increase tree mortality rates.

To study how lianas affect carbon cycling, we established a network of 16 80 x 80 meter plots in a seasonally moist tropical forest in Panama that has average liana abundance when compared to other tropical forests worldwide.  After surveying all trees and lianas, lianas were removed from eight of the plots by cutting all lianas rooted in the plots at the base with machetes.  This resulted in two sets of plots to compare: forest plots that contained lianas and forests without lianas.  We tracked how the presence or absence of lianas affected tree growth and mortality, resources like soil moisture and light availability, seedling growth, and tree reproduction for four years. 

Using sap flow sensors to monitor tree physiological responses, we found that trees responded almost instantaneously to liana removal, which provided strong evidence that lianas compete strongly with trees and negatively affect tree performance.  In the longer term, this translated into lower growth rates of trees when lianas were present, compared to tree growth rates in the liana-free forest plots.  At the ecosystem scale when lianas are absent, forest productivity is diverted to build tree trunks, which are a long-term store for carbon.  When lianas are present, more photosynthate is used to build leaf tissue as opposed to tree trunks.  These results suggest that the ability of tropical forests to act as a sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide will decrease as liana abundances in the forest increase.  Moreover, in the presence of lianas, trees produced fewer flowers and fruits compared to trees in the forests without lianas.  This suggests that the negative effects of increasing lianas may also ramify to other trophic levels in the forest, as many animals rely on fruits and nectar or pollen from flowers as a food source.  Collectively, results from this project have revealed how lianas affect multiple aspects of the structure and function of tropical forests, and suggest how these processes may change as lianas continue to increase in abundance.
